messageBody:
Hi, I am looking for some feedback into my work of extending JUnit's
capability to perform Data Driven Testing using annotations.You can find
the source code here :
https://github.com/anujgandharv/junit-theories-ext/
<https://github.com/anujgandharv/junit-theories-ext/>
Please enter any suggestions/improvements/requests to the GitHub
repository or main me directly at anuj.gandharv@...
These are some of the extensions to the existing JUnit Theories runner :
CASE 1: Specify test data in the form of CSV file. You can choose the
type of file containing the data:(CSV,EXCEL,XML or CUSTOM)
@Theory@TestData(filePaths = { "getTestData.csv" }, fileType =
FileType.CSV) //This is new annotation definedpublic void
testGetItems(@DataProvider()Map<String, String> inputData) {
.....# The Map corresponds to a single row of test data in the CSV
file.
}
CASE 2: Gives user flexibility to provide its own custom loader, in case
the framework does not support the data file :
@Theory@TestData(filePaths = { "getItemsData.dat" }, fileType =
FileType.CUSTOM)@CustomLoader(loader = MyDataLoader.class)public void
testWithCustomLoader(@DataProvider()Map<String, String> inputData) {
# The Map corresponds to a single row of test data in the .dat file.
}
CASE 3: Auto detects and populates user defined objects:
@Theory@TestData(filePaths = { "getItemsData.csv" })public void
testWithStrongParameters(@DataProvider()LibraryId id ,
@DataProvider(paramName="itemid") ItemId itemId) { # DataProvide
annotation tells the framework that the parameter's value should be
provided by the framework. It can also take an optional paramName
which gives more control over the data to the user.
}
OR
@Theory@TestData(filePaths = { "getItemsData.csv" })public void
testConverter(@DataProvider() Item item){ Assert.assertNotNull(item);
System.out.println(item.getDescription() + item.getItemId() +
item.getItemType());
}
